title: Homeschooling on rise as some parents teach children themselves to avoid prosecution for truancy
text:
Homeschooling is on the rise, figures show, with some parents teaching their children themselves to avoid prosecution and fines.

According to research by Ofsted, students are in some cases removed from mainstream secondary schools to be home education because their parents want to “avoid pressures” from their children's school over attendance.

The number of children being homeschooled is “increasingly rapidly”, the schools watchdog said. A survey conducted by the Association of Directors of Children’s Services last November found that there were 57,873 children educated at home, a 27 per cent rise on the previous year.

“Parents can move children to home education to avoid pressures at school, for example to avoid prosecution for non-attendance, and permanent exclusions,” the Ofsted report said.

“For some parents, facing fines or prosecution for a child missing school triggered a move a child to home education.”

The inspectorate's study, based on research with families, schools and councils in the East Midlands, investigated why children move to home education from secondary school. It noted that it was often unclear whether parents who decided who home educate their children to avoid paying penalty notices were doing so as a tactic to “play the system”.

The report went on to explain that parents who were issued with penalty notices for allowing their children to miss school often did so as a result of their “needs not being met”.

Pupils are only allowed to miss school during term time if they are ill or if they have got advance permission from a teacher. Local councils can take various forms of legal action against parents who allow their children to miss school for any other reason.

This could be forcing them to attend parenting classes, appointing a child supervisor or issuing a penalty notice where parents have to pay a fine.

Failure to comply with these measures could lead to prosecution. Ofsted said that it also found evidence of pupils being “off-rolled” into home education, meaning teachers have forced a family to remove their children from school rather than it being their choice.

The report added that for many families, home education is not a preferred choice but a last resort amid a breakdown in relationships with schools.

Special educational needs, medical and behavioural reasons are among the main motives for pupils being moved out of schools, Ofsted's new paper says. Chief inspector Amanda Spielman said children should not switch to home education "simply to resolve difficulties in schools".

The report found that the length of time for a child to be moved to home education can be very short. "The period between a parent finding out about the possibility of home education and their child leaving school can be as little as one day," inspectors said. "In extreme circumstances, moving a child to home education took as little as a day”.

Ms Spielman, said: "Home education is a legitimate parental choice and can be a positive decision when parents are well equipped to provide a good education.

"However, children should not be moved to home education simply to resolve difficulties in school.”
description: Homeschooling is on the rise, figures show, with some parents teaching their children themselves to avoid prosecution and fines.
